title: Contributing
text: Submit issue issues page

title: Contributing
text: Fork repository Github account Clone version account machine account Make sure track progress upstream .e., version wowi nutspatial/wowi, making changes make sure pull changes upstream either git fetch upstream merge later git pull upstream fetch merge one step Make changes new feature branch Please write test tests changes affect code just documentation Push changes account Submit pull request nutspatial/wowi
code: git clone https://github.com/<yourgithubusername>/wowi.git git remote add upstream https://github.com/nutspatial/wowi.git

title: Authors and Citation
text: Tomás Zaba. Author, maintainer, copyright holder.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Tomás Zaba (2025). wowi: Utilities detecting statistically significant spatial clusters high acute malnutrition rates using SaTScan's Bernoulli spatial-scan model. R package version 0.1.0, https://nutspatial.github.io/wowi/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {wowi: Utilities for detecting statistically significant spatial clusters of high acute malnutrition rates using SaTScan's Bernoulli spatial-scan model},   author = {{Tomás Zaba}},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://nutspatial.github.io/wowi/}, }

what: Detect Spatial Clusters of High Acute Malnutrition Rates
title: Detect Spatial Clusters of High Acute Malnutrition Rates
text: Child acute malnutrition can lead death identified treated time. Driven combination diverse factors, often exhibits spatial variation. levels acute malnutrition commonly measured surveys representative area interest. survey results used inform programme responses — find treat affected children. end, programme managers require actionable insights acute malnutrition prevalent. essential prioritising interventions, especially resources limited. wowi - expression meaning “” Elómwè, local language spoken central-northern Mozambique - provides convenient utilities purpose. identifies locations across survey area acute malnutrition significantly high (hotspots) low (coldspots), unlikely due chance alone. wowi wrapper package built top rsatscan package, enables use SaTScan software within R. rsatscan provides general-purpose functionality, wowi specifically made acute malnutrition analysis, tailoring tools needs nutrition-focused spatial investigations. use wowi, must SaTScan installed machine, along mwana R package preprocessing anthropometric data.

title: Detect Spatial Clusters of High Acute Malnutrition Rates
text: wowi yet CRAN can installed :

title: Detect Spatial Clusters of High Acute Malnutrition Rates
text: takes dataset GPS coordinates (latitude longitude), scans clusters acute malnutrition—either high low, depending user’s specification—across survey area, returns three main outputs: (1) interactive HTML map displaying detected clusters (previewed ); (2) .txt file containing results; (3) table summary statistics metadata parsed .txt file. package particularly handy working datasets span multiple areas administrative units, enabling consistent, area-wise detection hotspots coldspots. also generates additional GIS-based files (e.g., shapefiles), can useful geospatial manipulation integration mapping workflows.

what: A glimpse of detected hotspots and coldspots
title: Detect Spatial Clusters of High Acute Malnutrition Rates
text: Red bubble: hotspot; blue bubble: coldspot; Size bubble: span spot.

what: A glimpse of the summary table
title: Detect Spatial Clusters of High Acute Malnutrition Rates
code: ## # A tibble: 2 × 18 ##  survey_area nr_EAs total_children total_cases `%_cases` location_ids   geo   radius span  children n_cases expected_cases observedExpected relative_risk ##  <chr>        <int>          <int>       <int>     <dbl> <chr>          <chr> <chr>  <chr>    <int>   <int>          <dbl>            <dbl>         <dbl> ## 1 District        36            532         104        19 23,24,26,25,3… 13.6… 1.43 … 1.88…      170       4           33.2             0.12         0.085 ## 2 District        36            532         104        19 16,20,14,12,1… 13.8… 26.24… 43.5…      258      84           50.4             1.67         4.46  ## # ℹ 4 more variables: `%_cases_in_area` <dbl>, log_lik_ratio <dbl>, pvalue <dbl>, ipc_amn <chr>

title: Detect Spatial Clusters of High Acute Malnutrition Rates
text: use wowi package work, please cite using suggested citation provided call citation() function follows:
code: citation("wowi") #> To cite wowi in publications use: #>  #>   Tomás Zaba (2025). _wowi: Utilities for detecting statistically #>   significant spatial clusters of high acute malnutrition rates using #>   SaTScan's Bernoulli spatial-scan model_. R package version 0.1.0, #>   <https://nutspatial.github.io/wowi/>. #>  #> A BibTeX entry for LaTeX users is #>  #>   @Manual{, #>     title = {wowi: Utilities for detecting statistically significant spatial clusters of high acute malnutrition rates using SaTScan's Bernoulli spatial-scan model}, #>     author = {{Tomás Zaba}}, #>     year = {2025}, #>     note = {R package version 0.1.0}, #>     url = {https://nutspatial.github.io/wowi/}, #>   }

what: wowi: Detect Spatial Clusters of High Acute Malnutrition Rates — wowi-package
title: wowi: Detect Spatial Clusters of High Acute Malnutrition Rates — wowi-package
text: Utilities detecting statistically significant spatial clusters high acute malnutrition rates using SaTScan's Bernoulli spatial-scan model.

title: wowi: Detect Spatial Clusters of High Acute Malnutrition Rates — wowi-package
text: Maintainer: Tomás Zaba tomas.zaba@outlook.com (ORCID) [copyright holder]

what: Configure SaTScan for a Bernoulli purely spatial scan — ww_configure_satscan
title: Configure SaTScan for a Bernoulli purely spatial scan — ww_configure_satscan
text: Defines analysis parameters required SaTScan's GUI conduct Bernoulli-based purely spatial scan, either detect clusters high rates acute malnutrition high low rates. User input limited specifying analysis area filename, destination directory parameters file, SaTScan version use, type clusters detected. parameters pre-defined function.

title: Configure SaTScan for a Bernoulli purely spatial scan — ww_configure_satscan
code: ww_configure_satscan(   filename = character(),   params_dir = character(),   satscan_version = character(),   .scan_for = c("high-rates", "high-low-rates") )

title: Configure SaTScan for a Bernoulli purely spatial scan — ww_configure_satscan
text: filename quoted string identifying analysis area. params_dir quoted string folder directory parameters file (produced function) saved. can directory specified ww_wrangle_data(). satscan_version quoted string indicating version SaTScan installed user's computer. Internally, value checked latest available version. older, warning issued link SaTScan’s website. Although analysis interrupted, recommended use latest version. .scan_for quoted string indicating type clusters scan . scan high-rate clusters , set .scan_for = "high-rates". scan high low rates, set .scan_for = "high-low-rates".

title: Configure SaTScan for a Bernoulli purely spatial scan — ww_configure_satscan
text: information Bernoulli purely spatial scans, refer SaTScan technical documentation available : https://www.satscan.org/techdoc.html.

title: Configure SaTScan for a Bernoulli purely spatial scan — ww_configure_satscan
text: Kulldorff, M. (2022) SaTScan user guide version 10.1. Available : https://www.satscan.org/.

title: Configure SaTScan for a Bernoulli purely spatial scan — ww_configure_satscan
code: ## Given a temporary directory ---- tmp <- withr::local_tempdir() directory <- file.path(tmp, "input-files")  ## Wrangle data with `{mwana}` ---- x <- anthro |>   dplyr::rename(longitude = x, latitude = y) |>   mwana::mw_wrangle_wfhz(     sex = sex,     .recode_sex = TRUE,     weight = weight,     height = height   ) |>   mwana::define_wasting(     zscores = wfhz,     .by = "zscores",     edema = oedema   ) #> ================================================================================  ## Apply the function ---- ww_wrangle_data(   .data = x,   filename = "Locality",   dir = directory,   .gam_based = "wfhz" ) #> [1] "/tmp/RtmpExbyO2/file1c65df4a7f9/input-files/Locality"  library(rsatscan) # important to make `{wowi}` access `{rsatscan}`-specific eviroment #> rsatscan only does anything useful if you have SaTScan #> See http://www.satscan.org/ for free access  #### Configure SaTScan ---- do.call(   what = ww_configure_satscan,   args = list(     filename = "Locality",     params_dir = directory,     satscan_version = "10.3.2",     .scan_for = "high-low-rates"   ) )  ## Show file's content ---- file.show(file.path(tmp, "input-files/Locality.prm"))

what: Run SaTScan for Bernoulli purely spatial scan to detect statistically significant clusters of acute malnutrition — ww_run_satscan
title: Run SaTScan for Bernoulli purely spatial scan to detect statistically significant clusters of acute malnutrition — ww_run_satscan
text: Detect statistically significant spatial clusters acute malnutrition rates, including high-high--low clusters. ww_run_satscan() wrapper function interacts SaTScan GUI via {rsatscan} package. internally calls ww_wrangle_data() ww_configure_satscan(), allowing users skip two steps workflow instead call ww_run_satscan() directly.

title: Run SaTScan for Bernoulli purely spatial scan to detect statistically significant clusters of acute malnutrition — ww_run_satscan
code: ww_run_satscan(   .data,   filename = NULL,   dir = character(),   params_dir = dir,   sslocation = character(),   ssbatchfilename = character(),   satscan_version,   .by_area = FALSE,   .scan_for = c("high-rates", "high-low-rates"),   .gam_based = c("wfhz", "muac", "combined"),   area = NULL,   cleanup = TRUE,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Run SaTScan for Bernoulli purely spatial scan to detect statistically significant clusters of acute malnutrition — ww_run_satscan
text: .data data frame object wrangled using mwana::mw_wrangle_*() functions. filename Optional. Used single-area analysis. Used identify analysis area. string quoted. dir quoted string folder directory files saved. params_dir quoted string folder directory parameters file (produced function) saved. Defaults value dir. sslocation quoted string indicating path SaTScan GUI installation. varies operating system (OS). macOS, typically "/Applications/SaTScan.app/Contents/app"; Windows, "C:/Program Files/SaTScan". ssbatchfilename quoted string specifying SaTScan batch file name. macOS, use "satscan"; Windows, use "SaTScanBatch64". satscan_version quoted string indicating version SaTScan installed user's computer. See ww_configure_satscan() details. .by_area Logical. TRUE, area-wise scan done. Defaults FALSE. .scan_for quoted string indicating type clusters scan . scan high-rate clusters , set .scan_for = "high-rates". scan high low rates, set .scan_for = "high-low-rates". .gam_based quoted string indicating criterion used define acute malnutrition. used identify right vector flagged values identified, excluded analysis. Default wfhz. area unquoted string variable containing analysis areas iteration. cleanup Logical. TRUE, deletes SaTScan output files directory function runs. verbose Logical. TRUE, displays SaTScan results R console run batch mode. especially useful scan takes long time.

title: Run SaTScan for Bernoulli purely spatial scan to detect statistically significant clusters of acute malnutrition — ww_run_satscan
text: set SaTScan output files, saved specified directory. full file names depend filename argument: filename.txt: plain-text summary results. filename.clustermap.html: interactive HTML map showing detected clusters, red bubbles high-rate clusters blue low-rate clusters. Shapefiles: collection spatial files suitable use GIS software.

title: Run SaTScan for Bernoulli purely spatial scan to detect statistically significant clusters of acute malnutrition — ww_run_satscan
text: geographical coordinates must provided latitude longitude values. input data uses different variable names, must renamed accordingly; otherwise, analysis aborted. Latitude corresponds Y-axis (north-south direction), longitude X-axis (east-west direction).

title: Run SaTScan for Bernoulli purely spatial scan to detect statistically significant clusters of acute malnutrition — ww_run_satscan
code: ## Wrangle data with `{mwana}` ---- x <- anthro |>   dplyr::rename(longitude = x, latitude = y) |>   mwana::mw_wrangle_wfhz(     sex = sex,     .recode_sex = TRUE,     weight = weight,     height = height   ) |>   mwana::define_wasting(     zscores = wfhz,     .by = "zscores",     edema = oedema   ) #> ================================================================================  #' ## Given a temporary directory ---- tmp <- withr::local_tempdir() directory <- file.path(tmp, "input-files")  ## Run satscan ---- library(rsatscan) # important to make `{wowi}` access `{rsatscan}`-specific eviroment  if (file.exists("/Applications/SaTScan.app/Contents/app/satscan")) {   results <- ww_run_satscan(     .data = x,     filename = "Locality",     dir = directory,     sslocation = "/Applications/SaTScan.app/Contents/app",     ssbatchfilename = "satscan",     satscan_version = "10.3.2",     .scan_for = "high-low-rates",     .gam_based = "wfhz",     .by_area = FALSE,     area = NULL,     verbose = FALSE,     cleanup = FALSE   ) }

what: Prepare SaTScan-required input data files for a Bernoulli spatial scan analysis and save them in a user-defined working directory — ww_wrangle_data
title: Prepare SaTScan-required input data files for a Bernoulli spatial scan analysis and save them in a user-defined working directory — ww_wrangle_data
text: SaTScan's Bernoulli-based spatial scan requires input data split cases, controls, geographical coordinates files, saved format readable software, placed directory can access. ww_wrangle_data() convenient function designed task. assumes input anthropometric data pre-processed using {mwana} data wrangling functions.

title: Prepare SaTScan-required input data files for a Bernoulli spatial scan analysis and save them in a user-defined working directory — ww_wrangle_data
code: ww_wrangle_data(   .data,   filename = character(),   dir = character(),   .gam_based = c("wfhz", "muac", "combined") )

title: Prepare SaTScan-required input data files for a Bernoulli spatial scan analysis and save them in a user-defined working directory — ww_wrangle_data
text: .data data frame object wrangled using mwana::mw_wrangle_*() functions. filename quoted string identifying analysis area. dir quoted string folder directory files saved. .gam_based quoted string indicating criterion used define acute malnutrition. used identify right vector flagged values identified, excluded analysis. Default wfhz.

title: Prepare SaTScan-required input data files for a Bernoulli spatial scan analysis and save them in a user-defined working directory — ww_wrangle_data
text: Three files created saved user-defined directory defined dir: .cas file cases, .ctl controls, .geo file geographical coordinates. full filenames incorporate use-defined filename string. .cas .ctl files two columns: first containing survey cluster enumeration area IDs, second containing 1s, representing either cases controls, respectively. length .cas file depends number positive acute malnutrition cases (gam == 1), .ctl file number negative cases (gam == 0). .geo file three columns: cluster enumeration area IDs, latitude, longitude.

title: Prepare SaTScan-required input data files for a Bernoulli spatial scan analysis and save them in a user-defined working directory — ww_wrangle_data
code: ## Given a temporary directory ---- tmp <- withr::local_tempdir() directory <- file.path(tmp, "input-files")  ## Wrangle data with `{mwana}` ---- x <- anthro |>   dplyr::rename(longitude = x, latitude = y) |>   mwana::mw_wrangle_wfhz(     sex = sex,     .recode_sex = TRUE,     weight = weight,     height = height   ) |>   mwana::define_wasting(     zscores = wfhz,     .by = "zscores",     edema = oedema   ) #> ================================================================================  ## Apply the function ---- ww_wrangle_data(   .data = x,   filename = "Locality",   dir = directory,   .gam_based = "wfhz" ) #> [1] "/tmp/RtmpExbyO2/file1c652c7e476c/input-files/Locality"  ## Show created files ---- list.files(file.path(tmp, "input-files")) #> [1] "Locality.cas" "Locality.ctl" "Locality.geo"  ## Display each files' content ---- file.show(file.path(tmp, "input-files/Locality.cas")) file.show(file.path(tmp, "input-files/Locality.ctl")) file.show(file.path(tmp, "input-files/Locality.geo"))

title: wowi 0.1.0
text: Initial pre-release version alpha-testing.
